name: Multiply Strings
title: Multiply Strings
content:
Given two non-negative integers num1 and num2 represented as strings, return the product of num1 and num2, also represented as a string.

Note: You must not use any built-in BigInteger library or convert the inputs to integer directly.

 

Example 1:

Input: num1 = "2", num2 = "3"
Output: "6"

Example 2:

Input: num1 = "123", num2 = "456"
Output: "56088"

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= num1.length, num2.length <= 200
  • num1 and num2 consist of digits only.
  • Both num1 and num2 do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself.

discussion_posts.name: bcronrath
discussion_posts.content: Honestly I don\'t understand why these type of questions exist.  They should be removed, or leetcode should at least build in a way to have validation rules such as checking that variables aren\'t converted to integers.  Look at all the top runtime submissions for this one, literally they are one line where they just convert the strings to integers and multiply them, it\'s a joke.

discussion_posts.name: juicebox2
discussion_posts.content: Pretty silly question. I feel it teaches devs to try to find complex solutions to simple problems. Why wouldn\'t we leverage the basic functionality of a language and convert the strings to integer?\n

discussion_posts.name: Krrabs
discussion_posts.content:
For those saying, _why is it a medium? or it should be marked as easy._

In the question they specifically asked not to use `BigInt` or **convert** the input number **directly.**

That means in your solution there should never be an instance of `Integer/BigInt` having full value of inputs `num1` and `num2`.

No one is stopping you from doing that and solving your solution. But then, leaving comments like _"this is an easy question"_ you are only making a fool out of yourself.

discussion_posts.name: QuazarGuy
discussion_posts.content: This type of question should be removed so interviewers don\'t see it and think it\'s a good question. Implement a tedious and detailed already built-in function that\'s highly prone to error. I will reject a job if this type of question is asked. Test me on algorithms, not my ability to detect potential off-by-one errors.

discussion_posts.content: how does this have so many likes?

discussion_posts.name: Sanjeet-Kumar
discussion_posts.content:
![alt text](image url)![0_1497347622870_string.jpg](/assets/uploads/files/1497347627240-string-resized.jpg) 
Guys As i have found most difficulties to understand the problem.Here From the above picture we can see that the product of ith and jth number will be stroed in position i+j and i+j+1, 
i.e., res[i+j] is used to store the carry value and res[i+j+1] is used to rightmost digit of the sum.
![0_1497347660069_Screenshot (99).png](/assets/uploads/files/1497347665657-screenshot-99.png) 
I hope it will help you.

discussion_posts.name: A770192
discussion_posts.content: This should be marked as hard due to tricky implementation

discussion_posts.name: TranPhucVinh
discussion_posts.content:
This is my feedback for anyone who rejects or criticizes this problem, thinking it's useless. You are all wrong. This problem is extremely useful and has real-world applications, such as in calculators. The reason involves with the overflow issue.

Let's take an example with C/C++. You will certainly fail at this problem if you represent those strings using the largest data type, i.e., "long long" with a MAX_VAL of 9223372036854775807. Converting "string number" to "long number" or "int number" isn't how calculators operate in real life, as you can easily notice that all calculators nowadays can multiply numbers bigger than the long long MAX_VAL.

That's why the solution to perform multiplication with two string numbers manually comes into play.
